This is one of my favorite movies of all time. It's an inspiring underdog story but it's also a very touching love story. The film was written by Sylvester Stallone when he was going through a tough time. He took a few real events from his life, and added them into this movie. His character, Rocky Balboa, is a very humble and fun person and without his personality being the way it is, the movie wouldn't have been as good. He is developed very well and so are the supporting characters. Burt Young plays Paulie, a friend of Rocky's. Burgess Meredith plays Mickey, the owner of the gym Rocky fights and trains at. Mickey is one of the greatest characters ever put into film, he's hilarious but also very good hearted and smart. Talia Shire plays Adrian, Paulie's shy sister that works at a pet shop. Rocky and Adrians relationship is very well done, and the reason why is because despite her being the way she is, Rocky see's the beauty in her, and he allows her to be herself and you as the audience really start to feel for her character throughout the movie. Carl Weathers play Apollo Creed, who wants to challenge an underdog in the ring, he picks Rocky because of his nickname, The Italian Stallion. The story is rather predictable, but it doesn't stop the movie from being a masterpiece. The fight is great, the ending is satisfying, the acting is amazing, and the movie as a whole is definitely worth watching.
Rocky has more heart than most films combined. And Stallone's stellar acting and script give us one of the greatest film characters ever conceived.

Quite possibly the greatest sports movie ever made, Rocky is the penultimate boxing film that made Stallone a star.  The Rocky franchise has been emulated, parodied, and quoted to death, causing people to forget just how great the original film is.  At its roots, Rocky is a love story with a lot of heart.  I have always felt like Stallone is a heck of a lot smarter than he gets credit for (he wrote the script after all), and his smartest move of all may have been capitalizing on his slow-speaking persona by translating it to the screen and creating one of the most likeable, heroic characters in film history.  The film is brilliantly cast with actors who come across as average joes trying to make ends meet.  Carl Weathers (one of my favorite 80's stars) is the perfect antithesis to the Rocky character as smooth-talking heavyweight champ Apollo Creed.  His rivalry with Rocky is perfectly laid out, leading to an epic battle in the ring.

The fact that Stallone really did train like a boxer for the role and became something of an expert on the pugilistic art only adds to the realism. The storyline is fairly simlistic, underdog overcoming all the odds to triumph stuff, and the sub-plot lovestory sits slightly incongruously within the picture, but overall it's good watchable entertainment, even for the non sports fans.

Embarrassingly naive and proud of its imperialistic step into cinema. Stereotyping sports movies as dim vanity projects, it probably unleashed a constricted wave of  reducing the genre to simplistic storylines, cheesy acting, deflatable machismo for years, in addition to limiting the sports-movie quality expectancy at present, explaining the few number of more (what we have to call) sophisticated pictures like Rudy and Remember the Titans. Where films on the other side of the globe were already working on incorporating believable drama into their thrilling action (Asian martial arts movies, for one), here we're stuck with two hours of a camera aimlessly following around a lonely, unproductive chum who could probably have neanderthal impersonations as his stunt double. Oh, but the action is so real, man. It makes clashing action figures placed behind a cut-out soap box television screen a thing of the past, man. Plus, that guy up there feels my underdog pain and conveniently offers some hope with its priceless inspirational undercurrent. Indeed to the latter, but nah, man, the low budget is plainly visible, and worse it's used as a justification for careless and inconsiderate filming mechanisms, perhaps the reason why sports films as we know them are horribly subjective and unappealing most of the time. You're better off with the upped energy in actual boxing footage, something I never before pictured myself recommending.

The series' final episode tells a more convincing, moving story, but as portrayed in this opening chapter the character (not to mention that music) rightfully deserves its iconic status.

Rocky is my favorite movie of all time. Well, it's tied with the Lord of the Rings...and if you forced me to choose, I would stick with the Lord of the Rings trilogy, but, that doesn't stop me from calling this my favorite anyway. There's something magical about it that I can't explain....but, since you're reading this review, you'll realize that I tried explaining anyway!

Everyone knows the story by now...or they think they do...judging by the ratings people have given this film, I seriously doubt they've watched this movie recently. Chances are they're basing their opinions off the 'meh' Rocky 3 and the complete jokes that were 4 and 5. Revisiting this film time and time again, I am always struck by how different this film was from its ridiculous sequels (2 and 6 being the exceptions). The original Rocky is quiet and subtle, keeping its focus on the inspiring story and, more importantly, the wonderful characters. The setting is dark and dirty. It's a far cry from what many people associate with Rocky, and it'll probably throw off those who are expecting mindless entertainment as in the third and fourth films. That aside, there's just no denying the power of the original.

Sylvester Stallone cemented himself as one of the greatest actors of all time, giving one of the finest performances ever seen on film. It's a shame what happened to his career, but at least he got to prove himself once more with the final Rocky film. His writing is flawless as well. He gives every character a moment to shine and he never sinks to over the top sentimentality as he would in later films.

Talia Shire is absolutely stunning as Adrian...she says so much in just facial expressions, and you nearly forget that she doesn't have much dialogue for a good portion of the film's running time. 

Burt Young's performance as Paulie is another remarkable thing. Here is a guy you should hate, but you somehow can't. Thanks to the writing and the powerful acting of Young, Paulie is incredibly sympathetic.

Carl Weathers, in his big acting debut, is a complete natural. He embodies Apollo Creed in all his glory. Arrogant, fast-talking, good-natured...there's no way you can call this guy an antagonist. He's too likable.

Finally, there's the character of Mickey, played to perfection by the late Burgess Meredith. Both he and Stallone were nominated for acting Oscars and neither of them won. This is an absolute disgrace. Burgess' performance is iconic and has gone down in history as such. The scene in which he attempts to convince Rocky to let him be his manager is one of the finest on celluloid and that one alone proves that they both deserved Oscars.

All these performances, the script, and the brilliant, pitch-perfect directing from John G. Avildsen make the movie work, but there's one final element that really cements this as one of the greats. The score. Bill Conti's beautiful piano plays the solemn version of the Rocky theme, reminding us of the hardships these characters are going through. When the theme finally erupts in all its glory during the training montage, it takes every ounce of effort to keep yourself from cheering outloud and upsetting the neighbors. It simply is remarkable.

Rocky was the little movie that could. Made for a shoestring budget (reportedly under $1 million), this film went on to become one of the highest grossing of all time and spawned all the mediocre sequels that turned the character and Stallone into a joke (once again, may I remind you that I disclude the second and sixth because I thought they were both great). It was nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including Best Acting nods for Stallone, Shire, Meredith, and Young, Original Screenplay, Original Song, and Sound. It won Best Picture, Best Directing, and Best Editing. It also earned its place on the American Film Institute's list of the top 100 movies of all time (#57). This film is a timeless classic about one man's journey to prove to the world and, more importantly, himself that he can go the distance. All the elements combine perfectly to make this one of the best of all time. Stop pretending you've seen this movie if you've only seen the later ones. You have no idea what you're missing.

One of films' better underdog tales -- both in terms of the story and the career of Sylvester Stallone. I've always dug the '70s vibe which allows for a slow build and fully realized characters over just servicing the plot. This pays off once we actually get to the fight, and you realize how invested you are in the outcome. 'Rocky' also plays with sports movie conventionality and doesn't offer typical resolutions. Almost from release, 'Rocky' got a rep for being overly-earnest schmaltz, but there's always room for those type of pictures if they're well done.

Rocky is the quintessential underdog movie that has stood the test of time thanks to its great script, iconic music, and fantastic acting from Stallone and company. The classic story about a down-on-his-luck boxer who gets a shot at the big-time is semi-autobiographical of Stallone's struggles in Hollywood and how he refused to sell his script unless he could play Rocky, becoming a self-made movie star! His acting as a stereotypical, Italian bruiser-type is a little grating at first, but he slips comfortably into the role and you definitely root for him as the film goes on. The supporting cast is exceptional with great work from Burgess Meredith, Talia Shire, Burt Young, and of course: Carl Weathers as Rocky's opponent, Apollo Creed! Rocky's humble beginnings as an enforcer for a mobster was something I didn't expect and it adds a great level of drama to the character as he's struggling to become a better person and be more than just a meat-head. Also to be noted is the iconic theme for Rocky, Flying High Now that jacks you up and makes you feel like you could take on the world! To my surprise, I actually wasn't right about the film's conclusion, thinking I knew how it ended and it was a welcome surprise to be shocked by such a famous movie's ending after all of my preconceptions. This truly is a classic and much like the unforgettable scene of Rocky reaching the top of the steps, the film was a complete triumph and won three oscars including best picture, which was well-deserved! Do yourself a favour, and don't wait as long as I did to watch this outstanding film.

Perhaps only secondary to Raging Bull as the quintessential boxing movie, Rocky serves as not quite a bio-epic but rather what seems to be by today's standard the conventional under-dog story. It may not be original in that respect but it perfects the formula beyond any trite anchors which may have held it back. Thanks largely to a top-notch script and outstanding performance by Sylvester Stallone (let's not forget Burgess Meredith as Mick) this boxing story leaps beyond it's somewhat predictable outcome and envelopes you so deeply within its world that you can't help but become emotionally involved, the build-up towards the climatic fight between Rocky and Apollo is well worth it, and although you've seen this before, a no-body gets a shot at the big time and the whole movie is spent witnessing his growth, well yeah so what, Rocky makes it not only entertaining but gripping in certain moments, adding a nice dynamic between the somewhat blunt and obtrusive Rocky and the shy introverted Adrian. Theres more going on here than meets the eye in some respects, still it doesn't exactly break any formulas but rather delivers it so wonderfully, it's greatness can't help but be credited.

You see Rocky Balboa as a scrap in the beginning, he's old past his prime, washed up-in a sense, his potential has been wasted, or rather never realized. So what do you get with an aging fighter who's given the opportunity to prove that his prime wasn't wasted but still has yet to come? Rocky is given the chance to do this and ultimately it's a question of whether he can mentally. Beneath Rocky's unsophisticated brutish nature is a sympathetic character, and that's where the film is most relatable. We get to know Rocky throughout the movie up to the final fight and watch his growth through the development of other characters, by the end of the film everyones in Rocky's corner unanimously, because he is so representative of something much larger, the humble man rising to overcome all odds and take on the world. Yeah, it's somewhat cliche, and generic by all account but as you'll see from how well done the film is, it feels almost original, and that's thanks in large part to the films outstanding performances.

Many movies would follow the formula of Rocky, few have executed it as well. It's the classic under-dog story with characters deep enough to keep you engaged. Burgess Meredith as the aging trainer Mick almost makes the movie worth it by himself. The scene where Mick confronts Rocky about becoming his trainer now that Rocky has a shot at the title, and Rocky's ensuing tirade may be one of the more poignant and well done scenes. You see every bit of frustration that Rocky's feeling, all his emotion comes full surface, because under his demeanor is someone sympathetic yet the fighter in him all also prevails. No one expects Rocky to win, Rocky's fight against Apollo is supposed to be a publicity stunt, Rocky's the only one who goes in thinking it's going to be a fight. That's all Rocky wants, to give Apollo a fight, to do something no ones done before and go the distance. It's well written and well acted but it also has the intangible qualities which make it great. The film is inspirational by all conventions but much like Rocky Balboa himself it's all heart. It works.

Rocky is a solid boxing drama that is probably when of the best boxing films ever made. Not only is that but this probably one of the best films that Sly has ever done. Although nowadays boxing films are almost a cliché, Rocky still remains a classic because it was one of the first fight films to feature an underdog character. That to me is something that cannot be duplicated. No matter how many boxing films have come after Rocky, this film along with Raging Bull is still the standard boxing dramas, and the ones that are truly worth seeing. Rocky is a brilliant film that is a definite classic, and if you really want to watch the inspirational film, pick up this one. The film features a brilliant performance by Sylvester Stallone, who delivers as Rocky Balboa. Like I previously stated, this is the film to watch if you want a terrific sports drama. What makes Rocky so special is the fact that it was made when Sports dramas were minimalistic in the sense that they didn't really have them back then. Nowadays it seems that every year there's some sort of drama and 95% of time it's about boxing. Rocky is a true original, and no matter how many films have come after it trying to duplicate its formula, there can be only one, and it's Rocky. The story is terrific, the acting incredible and the directing is terrific. No wonder it has stood the test of time, and it's refreshing no matter how many times you've seen it, and no matter how many films try to duplicate its underdog story. If you want the classic original underdog, Rocky Balboa is his name.

Rocky is considered the most inspirational and influential sports film of all time, but it is more than just that. While the film opens with a boxing match, it is brief. From there on, viewers get insight into the life of the protagonist. We learn that Rocky Balboa is a working class man, a boxer with a lot of heart and potential who is held back by his status in life. He is a lone wolf in a cold dark world, and the story plays on this a lot. It is a slow film, but it really emphasizes the deep nature of its protagonist through this. It works to create a touching sentiment which really gives the film a lot of soul. Rocky is a classic because it is far from a shallow, it goes to many extents to ensure that its protagonist is likable and heroic in the best sense of the words. The film doesn't tell much of Rocky's past, but it captures his present and future very well by conveying the way the simple nature of the lower class man before developing the story more. We see Rocky change as his relationships progress, as his passion enlightens and as he is given once in a lifetime opportunity. The story is inspiring not just as a sports film but also because Rocky Balboa is a man triumphing over the limitations he is stuck with in life, mainly his lower class setting and the issues he has in connecting to people. Frankly, Rocky is a complicated character and the screenplay rises the common story motifs above its potential one-dimensionality to create a thoroughly touching tale. Sylvester Stallone's screenplay in Rocky is brilliant, the finest thing he has ever written. He redefines the sports underdog tale for a generation with his story of redemption and inspirational, full of strong characters and passion which is unmatched by nearly any film in cinema. Rocky is the original sports movie, the original underdog tale. It isn't flawless, but its inspiring legacy is undeniable. The characterisation of Rocky as a man who can take so much from the world but just keep going is an unforgettably optimistic view of life even in hard times, though it is not cheesy and does not turn the tale into an overly optimistic Hollywood movie. 
Rocky gains a lot of passion from the firm directorial work of John G. Avildsen. With a passionate intention to inspire audiences, he puts his heart and soul into Sylvester Stallone's screenplay and takes it all the way to the end. He puts a lot of life into the film and ensures that the atmosphere is always perfect. Capturing a combination of inspiration and grit, Rocky feels like a tale of opportunity and redemption but also one of survival due to the harsh nature of Rocky's street life. There is so much passion in the film that is unforgettable, and the John G. Avildsen captures everything well. As well as capitalising on the street scenery of the film, Rocky has a great visual palette to it thanks to ideal lighting. Everything is filmed well and the cinematography skilfully emphasizes the facial expressions of the actors as they approach the material intensively. But more impressively, the cinematography captures the boxing choreography incredibly well which is then edited with power. The boxing scenes in Rocky are incredibly powerful, and though they are few, they leave unforgettable imagery with the viewer.
But perhaps the most unforgettable aspect of Rocky's styls is the musical score. Featuring some inspiring pieces, Rocky pefectly sets a gentle but inspiring mood for some scenes while it intensifies in others to really empower the rough nature of the boxing in the film. Yet it does not top there because the musical score gets thoroughly touching during some of its most gentle and character-oriented moments, so Rocky is able to go between grit, energy and sympathy very well in its atmosphere. The soundtrack to Rocky and it's iconic theme "Gonna Fly Now" are unforgettable.
And to ensure a human touch, Rocky is flawlessly cast.
Sylvester Stallone's performance as Rocky is absolutely iconic. In the physical sense, Sylvester Stallone stands strong and handles the actual boxing choreography incredibly. He floats like a butterfly and stings like a bee, really stepping up to the challenge fearlessly well. But what is more impressive is the heart in his performance. Capturing the lower class and less educated nature of the character while also conveying his sense of grit and passionate spirit, Sylvester Stallone's breakthrough role is one which puts in mind a young Marlon Brando. He plays Rocky as a powerful fighter, but he puts more heart into the role than you would ever expect simply because he plays on the more subtle emotional elements of the character nicely during many scenes. One scene in Rocky depicts Sylvester Stallone delivering a soliloquy which is unforgettable due to the simplicity and gentle nature of the scene, as well as the fact that there is nothing to hide in the moment. It is all just Sylvester Stallone lying there and pouring his soul out for viewers to see. It is brilliant, thoroughly touching and the endeavour of the soul that Rocky has. Sylvester Stallone's performance in Rocky is his most deep to date and ties with his performance as John Rambo in First Blood as his all time greatest.
Burgress Meredith is unforgettable as well. Capturing the rowdy nature of Micky Goldmill, Burgress Meredith is relentless with the harsh way that he throws his words at Rocky. He doesn't have to do anything but stare intensively and shout his anger out at Sylvester Stallone. The two share a powerful chemistry, and Burgress Meredith really comes off as a mentor by encouraging a sense of wisdom which surpasses the less than educated status of the character. Burgress Meredith finds the ideal balance and pursues his role with a sense of grit for the part, delivering a memorable performance.
Talia Shire is also wonderful. At the beginning of the tale she is a thoroughly introverted person who hides everything, but she slowly comes out of her shell as the tale progresses. We see her put more life into the performance and develop a strong chemistry with Sylvester Stallone, supporting the story by reminding us that the protagonist has someone worth winnning for who is supporting him every step of the way. Talia Shire's gentle performance allows her to develop life into her character very well every step of the way, and she does it wonderfully which makes her impossible to dislike.
Burt Young is also spot on. Keeping with the gritty nature of the film, Burt Young portrays Paulie Pennino is an uneducated and similarly gritty man in the spirit of his class. He captures the low status and ignorant nature of the character, even emphasizing his disrespect for his sister to reflect negatively on him while countering that with a strong chemistry with Sylvester Stallone. He is unlikable and yet likable at the same time, and that makes him an interesting character due to the way that he assits the characterizations of Rocky Balboa and Adrian Pennino in his own way.
Carl Weathers is a perfect casting decision as Apollo Creed. Capturing the Muhammed Ali sense of the role, Carl Weathers remains an outspoken and determined boxer in the role while adding a sense of egotism as means of touching on the commercial status of the character as the champ. He plays a likable and yet cocky character, and when he steps into the ring his fighting abilities are amazing. Carl Weathers puts up a hell of a fight against Sylvester Stallone, always changing his style to fit the mood but having no problem coming off as strong willed and determined even in the face of his own ego.

So due to its undeniable sense of inspiring work from Sylvester Stallone's screenplay and leading performance, impressively gritty directorial work from John G. Avildsen, astounding soundtrack and powerful assortment of supporting actors, Rocky is an unforgettably inspiring and touching sports classic.

Sylvester Stallone, my favorite actor of all time, rose to fame with this masterpiece that is complete with an amazing soundtrack (The whole series' has legendary music, but that's for later), a very likable cast, and the story of the ultimate underdog.

When I first saw Rocky in, what? 1985 or something? Well, I wasn't expecting much from it, but it not blew my expectations away, it took my expectations to the woods and brutally beat the shit out of them like Jason Voorhees. With every hit in the final match I found myself cheering for Rocky. I knew it wouldn't make a difference whether I cheered or not, but it was so exciting I couldn't bear not to.

The acting is top notch from Sylvester Stallone as Rocky, Burt Young as Pauly, Carl Weathers as Apollo, and ESPECIALLY Burgess Merideth as Micky, who delivers some of the greatest lines of all time, such as "You're gonna eat lightning, and you're gonna crap thunder!"

The movie never really got stale to me, I thought all the character's rich personality kept things interesting, like when he was supposed to break a man's thumb for not paying anything back, but decided against it, which is interesting because most people just don't have the heart that Rocky does. Burt Young is a complete douchebag at first glance, but he gets better as the series goes on. Apollo Creed is actually a pretty cool antagonist in this film, and you can just tell how much he loves his home country. Burgess Meredith also shows a lot of enthusiasm in his role, and really, the only performance I didn't like was Talia Shire's. I don't know, there's something about Adrian I never liked. In fact I found her rather annoying in the sequels, particularly Rocky 4.

Anyways, I could probably call this the greatest movie of all time with 100% honesty, but is it my favorite? Nah, in fact, there's another film in this series I like even more...

Rocky was a thoroughly refreshing and engaging film, in spite of its highly glamorized predictability. It had all the makings of a good drama - performance-wise, music-wise, and of course ending-wise. But above all, it had two remarkable actors - Sylvester Stallone as the openly brash title hero, and Talia Shire as his introverted, shy girlfriend Adrian. These two really lighted up the screen with their character contradiction - the one with "the body without brains", and the other "brains without the body", to paraphrase their own words. However, I personally thought Rocky had a pretty evident defect throughout its duration: it seemed too fast in its pace. This applied especially to all those key points in it, including Rocky and Adrian's relationship, and Rocky agreeing to take on Mickey as his manager (just after he shouts furiously at him). Other than that, it was a greatly enjoyable experience, and one that I feel was one of the most inspiring movies I have ever seen. It's definitely a must for all sports film enthusiasts (and for any film fan, for that matter), and would have been even more perfect, were it not for its fast pace.

The original Rocky is iconic, and launched one of the most influential cinema franchises.  Yet, this first installment is far subdued from what Rocky would become; delivering a smart edgy drama.  It's a quintessential populist story: down-and-out "everyman" Rocky Balboa gets a shot to go the distance with world heavyweight champion Apollo Creed in the Bicentennial Super Battle fight on New Year's Day.  Sylvester Stallone, Talia Shire, and Burgess Meredith all give strong performances (all Academy Award nominated).  And, composer Bill Conti crafts a brilliant score that carries the soul of the film.  Despite a few dated pieces of '70s style filmmaking, Rocky holds up as an extraordinary inspirational drama.

Rocky is the ultimate underdog story and one of the best sports films ever made. Rocky is one of the great all time classics and will be remembered long after we are gone.

Written in three days by Sylvester Stallone, Rocky is an old-fashioned fairytale brilliantly revamped to chime in with the depressed mood of the nineteen- seventies. Winner of best picture in 1976, Sly's underdog-hero set the standard for future American Dream movies. Seeing Rocky is a cinematic experience filled with emotion, intense passion and heart. The film's possession of realism, superb dialogue and a phenomenal music score by Bill Conti, transformed the face of cinema. However, it is not the action scenes that make Rocky so effective. Rocky isn't about the story, it's about a hero. Sylvester Stallone's performance as the Italian Stallion is sheer magic. Rocky is an authentic and touching portrait of a loser who becomes a winner in the things that matter. This is Sly's movie as he slugs his way through a heartfelt performance and delivers some cracking punches, both literally and emotionally. It's sometimes hard to remember what a great film Rocky is because its reputation has been hurt by too many unnecessary sequels, but watch it again and you soon realise why you felt so inspired and touched by Stallone's classic masterpiece.

What a classic movie. Rocky embodies what some call the "American story". Here's a guy who is beginning to realize that he amounts to nothing, that he's a bum. When given an opportunity, he finds himself and becomes great. His grit and determination, self-discipline and relentless focus, and support from loved ones turn Rocky into a champion; the perfect zero to hero story. Also, there's something great about boxing; it's a personal battle that can represent anything. In the case of Rocky, I think his battle was with everyone who ever put him down and even his own doubts, not so much with Apollo Creed. My buddy Nick once said "if you've got a problem with Rocky, you've got a problem with yourself." I'm not saying everybody HAS to like the movie, but the story is timeless and universal.

Rocky the american movie written by Stallone and starring himself as Rocky Balboa - The Italian stallion is perhaps the most awesome ,most crowd pleasing, most celebrated sports movie ever made to date. The movie is a celebration of humanity,of the hardships of Life and that big chance ; that one big chance which life gives us. Bolstered by brimming performances from Stallone , Talia shire and Burt Young this movie  is a masterpiece no matter what. That apologetic and sympathetic look in Stallone's face or the very heart warming  inspirational advices of the coach, that is what makes this movie a must watch. Rocky is treated as a piece of slime, he isn't respected and he is treated with contempt anywhere he goes. He gets the chance of a life time when 'Apollo Creed' the heavy weight champion just for plain publicity gives an underdog rookie a chance of his lifetime to got to the title shot straight off. All of a sudden he becomes a hero out there  and people who treated him as a piece of slime actually goes on to start helping him out. He gets an amateur trainer who for several years has been waiting for such an opportunity,even the training sequences are great. Nobody else other than stallone in the industry could have actually done that role in a more better way. Direction by Ray windelstone is amazing,powerful and will make you stand up and clap at the end. The score by John Bon jovi is great, it is pleasing and a motivating kind of music. The movie is not just about sports or winning a game like most sports dramas, this one's about human emotions of an underdog who wishes to rise above what he could achieve to prove that he is something in this world,it's about his love for a shy girl and the movie is about unfulfilled lives. This movie is more than any Sports movie it is a celebration of humanity, a very inspiring and motivational tale for all the people. 

My rating : A+

What can you say, it's a classic. And I must say that when I watched it the second time, I didn't remember just how slow this film is. But in this case the slowness is not a bad thing. I actually enjoyed how the movie takes its sweet time showing just what kind of a guy this Rocky really is. And while the ending is kind of disappointing, it's to be expected and quite frankly it would have felt cheap had the ending been any different. So yeah, the movie has problems, these no denying that, and it certainly doesn't appeal to everyone's tastes, but I personally enjoyed it. Stallone makes a great role in this one, though he's romance with Adrian (Talia Shire) is kind of forced. The movie has some really great scenes, some really great lines and the story is well-written - no matter how basic it is. So yeah, I liked, no matter how many problems this film has.

I've never understood boxing..it just makes so little sense.  Two men willingly beating the hell out of each other?  But there is something completely charming about Rocky.  Sylvester Stallone was not getting anywhere with his acting career, and then he wrote himself a film, a film about a guy who gets his chance to go the distance...and the film made him a megastar, he was able to go that distance.  Rocky is pretty well written, especially considering it was the first script Stallone wrote.  On top of the good writing...the whole cast is great, from Stallone as the dimwitted nice guy everyday schlub boxer and his shy timid girlfriend played by Talia Shire to Burgess Meredith as the grumpy old trainer Mick and Burt Young as the pathetic drunk Paulie.  Add in Carl Weathers as the showboating business minded champ Apollo Creed, and you have one of the strongest casts possible.  Like I said, the film has charm, and it manages to be enjoyable to someone like me who despises the whole idea of boxing in real life.

The originals are always the best.  This was the best of the Rocky movies.  Down and out boxer, goes for the championship, but shows a human side at the same time.  I am still amazed, though, that Adrienne (sp?) can have such fantastic diction by the end of the film, when she isn't stringing sentences together too coherently at the beginning.

This is one film I watched for the love of Oscar Club only. I'm sorry to say but I'm not big on boxing films, or Stallone for that matter. But, I confess, I did like it, didn't love it but appreciated the 70s vibe, the love story and the character of Rocky Balboa.

Balboa (Stallone) is a boxer at the end of his career. He's a cool dude, a nice guy with muscles. When he's not boxing he's working for a loan shark, intimidating customers. When heavyweight champ, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) loses his opponent to injury, he suggests finding a local talent to put on a show for the crowd. If the challenger wins, he takes home the title as World Champion. As if!  Creed chooses the Italian Stallion, Balboa.

Meanwhile, Rocky is getting all romantic with his friend's sister Adrian (Shire) who is a shy little thing. They go out on a very funny and awkward date, then Balboa makes his move and they're in love! Awwww. His focus then shifts to training: running, boxing and running, jogging, sprinting, punching large bags and carcasses, then more running, this time with a mean looking dog.

Then it's fight time. In one corner, there's the humble Italian Stallion and in the other, the stars and stripes clad and cocky Creed. Who will be left standing?

This is a great 70s flick. The music, the bouffant hair, the dramatic scenes with zooms. The first half plods by while the second is over before you can blink. Rocky and Adrian have a sweet romance - one might say it is true love. That will get the ladies watching and the punching, bloody scenes will keep the men keen.

I love a good rags to riches story. This is a film that ticks almost all of the Oscar boxes for me, but not quite. Perhaps because I'm not a huge fan of boxing. But it is a watchable film, so if you're in the mood, check it out!

'Rocky' Trivia: 

* A mere $1 million
* Stallone insisted he star in this film after selling the rights to producers, Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff.
* It was shot in 28 days
* Stallone wrote the script in 3 days ... but then it was rewritten 9 times.
* The character of Rocky Balboa is actually named Robert Balboa!
* Elvis wanted Stallone to bring him a copy of Rocky but Stallone was too scared of him so just sent the film.
* Stallone's dad rings the bell at the beginning of the fight and his brother is seen as one of the street people singing.
* When Gazzo (Joe Spinell) uses the inhaler it was not in the script, Spinell was actually having an asthma attack.
* The biggest expense was makeup

i wish i could give this movie more than 100 percent. if i could i would give it like a million percent. if theres such a thing as perfection in a movie its this movie. Stallone was the absolute perfect character for this movie and his love interest with the shy Talia Shire is easy to relate to and his "Cinderella" story makes your heart fill with joy and makes you want to stand up and cheer when he knocks Carl Weathers down and i found myself talking to the T.V. saying "Get up Rock! Get up! You can do it!" when he was knocked down in round 14. i was slightly irritated when the bell rang to end the fight, but i got over it when Talia Shire ran up on the ring at the end of the fight and hugged Rocky. the training scene with "Gonna Fly Now" will pump you up and make you wanna go headbutt a brick wall just to get rid of that excess adrenaline. Bill Conti did a phenomenal job with the music. John G. Avildsen and Sylvester Stallone did an unbelievable job with this movie and it is, in my opinion the greatest movie of all time; and ive seen the godfather. every time i watch this movie i get goose bumps and want to watch it again. A master piece. The classic story of a very lucky boxer with a unique opportunity makes Rocky simplty the movie that redifined the word "motivation". The cast is perfect, each feels like the character they perform. Each character develops and evolves, giving a satisfactory storytelling, without forgetting any key character. The music by Bill Conti is dark and shine, also fitting, and the Rocky Theme "Gonna Fly Now" is in the best scene and most iconic: the training, perfectionating the scene. The story is predictible, but the developing is unique. Each shot is accompanied by the right light and much dark, giving the film the correct tone to go on. Overall, the final product is perfectly crafted and concieved, starting the Rocky saga, ready to go all the way.
